thread.title: Dow Futures Extend Drop on IBM Sales Slump
thread.title_full: Dow Futures Extend Drop on IBM Sales Slump

title: Dow Futures Extend Drop on IBM Sales Slump
text:
Reprint 
NEW YORK ( TheStreet ) -- Stock futures traded mixed on Tuesday morning as investors digested a rush of earnings and crude oil struggled to hold above $50 a barrel. 
S&P 500 futures were flat, Dow Jones Industrial Average futures fell 0.07%, and Nasdaq futures added 0.16%. 
United Technologies ( UTX - Get Report ) shares were on watch after the defense contractor reported a mixed quarter. Net income of $1.81 a share beat analysts' estimates by a dime, while revenue of $16.33 billion fell 5% and missed estimates by $190 million. The company warned that future profit at its aerospace and elevator businesses would be lower than expected for 2015. 
IBM ( IBM - Get Report ) fell nearly 5% in premarket trading after sales plummeted for the 13th straight quarter. Revenue of $20.81 billion slid 14.6% from a year earlier, missing estimates by $140 million, as PC demand continued to fall. IBM affirmed its full-year guidance. 
Must Read: Warren Buffett's Top 10 Dividend Stocks 
Verizon ( VZ - Get Report ) slipped 1.3% on a mixed quarter, earning $1.04 a share on $32.22 billion in sales. Analysts expected $1.01 in net income on $32.45 billion in revenue. 
Harley-Davidson ( HOG - Get Report ) gained 2.8% despite a drop in quarterly motorcycle sales. Overall motorcycle sales fell 1.4%, driven by a 2.7% decline in the international market. Harley-Davidson downgraded 2015 guidance for shipments of motorcycles to 281,000 at the high end, below a previous forecast of 282,000 at the low end. 
Travelers ( TRV ) rose more than 2% after beating bottom-line quarterly estimates. The insurance holding company earned $2.52 a share, 39 cents better than expected, on $6.17 billion in revenue. 
Qualcomm ( QCOM ) gained nearly 3% on Wall Street Journal reports the chipmaker is considering a strategic breakup. The company could announce major changes, which may include significant layoffs, in its third-quarter earnings call on Wednesday afternoon. 
Shake Shack ( SHAK ) stumbled more than 3% in premarket trading after filing a secondary offering of 4 million shares of common stock on behalf of shareholders. Shake Shack will not receive any of the proceeds. 
Crude oil struggled to hold above $50 a barrel, extending losses after hitting its lowest point since early April on Monday. West Texas Intermediate crude fell 0.1% to $50.10 a barrel. 
Oil has been under pressure in recent weeks as a number of macro worries came to a head: Iran and six world powers agreed on a nuclear deal that would ease international sanctions; the likelihood of a Federal Reserve rate hike this year increased, pushing the safe-haven U.S. dollar higher; and the International Energy Agency warned that the market remains "massively oversupplied" in a report earlier in the month.
